content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Only 7% of people read terms and conditions
before clicking "I agree."

What could you be agreeing to without knowing?

objectives.description: Recognize the five essential elements that make a contract legally binding: offer, acceptance, consideration, capacity, legality.
Understand common legal terminology and contract clauses in financial agreements.
Evaluate contract terms to understand your rights, obligations, and potential financial risks.
Use contract literacy skills to protect your personal interests in financial transactions.

terms.definition: A legally enforceable agreement between two or more parties that creates mutual obligations.
terms.example: Apartment lease, phone plan, car loan, employment agreement, gym membership.

terms.definition: Something of value exchanged between parties‚Äîeach must give something for the contract to be valid.
terms.example: You pay rent; landlord provides housing. No consideration = gift, not contract.

terms.definition: Contract clauses, often in small text or buried in lengthy documents, containing important limitations, fees, or penalties.
terms.example: "Early termination fee: $500" or "Automatic renewal unless canceled 60 days prior."

terms.definition: Failure to fulfill the obligations outlined in a contract without a legal excuse.
terms.example: May result in penalties, fees, legal action, damage to credit, or repossession.

leftPanel.title: All Five Must Be Present
paragraphs: 1. Offer: A clear proposal to do or provide something specific.
2. Acceptance: Unconditional agreement to the offer's terms.
3. Consideration: Each party exchanges something of value.
4. Capacity: Parties must be legal age, mentally competent, not under duress.
5. Legality: The contract's purpose must be legal.

highlightBox.text: Missing any element = contract may be invalid or voidable.

infoCard.title: Quick Test:
items: "I'll give you my phone for free" = No consideration (gift)

layoutData.title: Contracts You'll Encounter Throughout Life
paragraphs: Each type has unique terms and implications you need to understand before signing:
bulletPoints: Lease Agreements: Rent, deposits, maintenance, termination penalties
Loan Agreements: Principal, interest, payment schedule, default terms
Service Contracts: Phone plans, internet, gym‚Äîwatch for auto-renewal!
Employment Contracts: Salary, benefits, non-compete clauses, termination
Purchase Agreements: Cars, real estate‚Äîhigh stakes, read carefully
Credit Agreements: Cards, lines of credit‚Äîknow the APR and fees

keyPoint.text: The more money involved, the more carefully you should read. Major contracts deserve hours of review, not minutes.

leftPanel.title: Essential Reading Strategies
paragraphs: 1. Read the ENTIRE contract‚Äînever sign without complete review.
2. Identify ALL financial obligations: payments, fees, penalties.
3. Locate termination terms: How do you exit? At what cost?
4. Watch for automatic renewal: Does it continue unless you cancel?
5. Find arbitration clauses: Do you give up the right to sue?

highlightBox.text: If you don't understand a term, research it or ask. Never assume it doesn't matter.

infoCard.title: Red Flag Phrases:
items: "Company may modify terms at any time"

layoutData.title: Important Terms Are Often Buried
paragraphs: Companies deliberately put unfavorable terms in small text or lengthy documents. The most important clauses are often the hardest to find:
bulletPoints: Arbitration Clauses: You can't sue in court or join class actions
Liability Limitations: The company isn't responsible for problems
Modification Clauses: They can change terms with minimal notice
Automatic Renewal: Continues charging unless you proactively cancel
Default Provisions: What happens if you miss a payment
Indemnification: You may be responsible for their legal costs

keyPoint.text: "I didn't read it" is NOT a legal defense. Your signature = you agreed. Courts enforce contracts as written.

leftPanel.title: Real Money at Stake
paragraphs: Signing contracts without reading can cost thousands of dollars and limit your future flexibility.
Non-compete clauses can prevent you from taking better jobs for months or years.
Perpetual payment cycles prevent wealth building‚Äîsubscription services, gym memberships, and loans you can't afford.

highlightBox.text: Contract literacy is empowerment. Understanding contracts lets you negotiate better terms and make informed decisions.

layoutData.title: Protecting Your Financial Future
paragraphs: Understanding contracts isn't about avoiding all agreements‚Äîit's about knowing what you're agreeing to:
bulletPoints: Avoid Unexpected Costs: Know all fees, penalties, and conditions upfront
Maintain Flexibility: Understand how and when you can exit if needed
Negotiate Better Terms: Many contract terms ARE negotiable if you ask
Prevent Legal Problems: Know your obligations before you commit
Build Wealth: Avoid traps that keep you paying perpetually
Protect Career Options: Understand non-compete and exclusivity clauses

keyPoint.text: Taking 30 minutes to read a contract can save you thousands of dollars and years of frustration.

leftPanel.title: Don't Assume Terms Are Fixed
paragraphs: Many people believe contracts are take-it-or-leave-it. In reality, especially for employment, leases, and services, negotiation is often possible.
The worst they can say is "no." Many businesses will modify terms to secure good customers or employees.
Approach professionally: Ask questions, express concerns, propose alternatives, get changes in writing.

highlightBox.text: Employers often respect candidates who carefully review contracts‚Äîit shows attention to detail and professionalism.

scenario.name: Aaliyah's Apartment Lease Trap
paragraphs: Aaliyah signed a 12-month lease without carefully reading the 15-page agreement. Three months later, she got a great job offer in another city.
When she tried to break her lease, she discovered: 60 days' notice required, subletting prohibited without a $500 fee, early termination = 2 months' rent + forfeited deposit.
Total cost to leave: $3,800 that she never anticipated.

scenario.name: Sofia's Informed Contract Negotiation
paragraphs: Sofia received a job offer at $52,000. Instead of signing immediately, she read all five pages carefully and researched unfamiliar terms.
She found a non-compete clause: couldn't work for competitors within 50 miles for 2 years. She also noticed a 90-day probationary period with no health benefits.
Sofia negotiated professionally: reduced non-compete to 1 year/25 miles, got benefits at 60 days. The employer agreed and appreciated her thoroughness!
